issue.title: Feature Request: Support gRPC prefix path on URL
issue.body:
### Is there an existing request for this feature?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues for this feature request and I know that duplicates will be closed

### Is your feature request related to a problem?

We use Envoy to routing and clustering our back-end services and we use prefix for routing between the services and some gRPC tools such as Kreya and BloomRPC support path on request URL but Postman doesn't support URL path and when I use prefix path on the URL like "grpc://localhost:1337/api" Postman raise error "Failed to parse DNS address dns:localhost:1337/api"

### Describe the solution you'd like

gRPC for calling methods use a string such as: /packagename.ServiceName/MethodName so if we have a request URL for example "grpc://localhost:1337/api" you can parse this URL and use host name and port (localhost:1337) for make connection to server and  if exists a path in the URL (/api in this URL) add into start of the method name before call it like as /api/packagename.ServiceName/MethodName.

thank you so much.

comment.body: Hey everyone, can someone share a demo repository to reproduce this behavior locally to fast-track the fix?

Postman App

Well, my gRPC server is deployed on AWS it's behind ALB and deployed to ECS cluster. I tried to use grpcurl tool and it works without any issue, so it's not up to my setup, it's postman thing. If you need more info please let me know. Thanks!

issue.title: URL Encoding not working
issue.body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the tracker for existing similar issues and I know that duplicates will be closed

### Describe the Issue

When "Encode URL Automatically" is enabled, the call request path is not being encoded for specific characters. The characters not being encoded are treated differently when used as a query parameter value. Attached are two screenshots displaying this behavior. The first screenshot is showing the GET request containing multiple # characters in the path and the console log showing the request made is not encoding this character. The second screenshot is showing when I make a request to a different endpoint where it accepts query parameters, the # character is being encoded in the request showing in the console.

### Steps To Reproduce

1. Open a new request
2. Enable the "Encode URL Automatically" setting
3. Update the uri path to include a # character
4. Submit the request and review the console log

Conflicting behavior replication steps
1. Open a new request
2. Enable the "Encode URL Automatically" setting
3. Add a query parameter with a value that includes the # character
4. Submit the request and review the console log

### Screenshots or Videos


![tempsnip2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/96807580/195424301-e3a6c9a5-dee6-467a-a011-88abbc1ba6a4.png)

![tempsnip](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/96807580/195423964-90f5c9a6-faaa-47b6-a6fd-c2f4851e9390.png)


### Operating System

Windows

### Postman Version

10.0.25

### Postman Platform

Postman App

### Additional Context?

_No response_

comment.body: @Ludatick This happens because `#` in a URL string represents a [URI fragment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/URI_fragment). The "Encode URL automatically" setting encodes reserved characters (as per WHATWG spec) in URL segments, but `#` holds a different meaning. It's working for the query-params input because the URL string has `%23`. As a workaround, I will suggest having this Pre-request script to encode `#`s before sending the request. ```js pm.request.url.update(pm.request.url.toString().replace(/#/g, '%23')); ```

issue.title: Support pm.sendRequest in gRPC scripts.
issue.body: ### Is there an existing request for this feature? - [X] I have searched the existing issues for this feature request and I know that duplicates will be closed ### Is your feature request related to a problem? In HTTP requests pre-request script, it is possible to send http requests with `pm.sendRequest` to perform actions before the request (e.g. retrieve a fresh access token for authentication/authorization), but it seems like the function is not supported in gRPC `Before Invoke` request scripts (see below). ### Describe the solution you'd like Support the function `pm.sendRequest` to send HTTP requests in gRPC scripts. ### Describe alternatives you've considered Checked available [external libraries available in scripts in postman](https://learning.postman.com/labs/postman-api-client/grpc-client/writing-scripts/postman-sandbox-api/#using-external-libraries) to see if one of them supported HTTP requests, but couldn't find any that did. ### Additional context _No response_

comment.body: @olaforest Sorry for the delayed response. We’ll enable this by the end of this month. 🤞🏻

issue.title: Support configuring GRPC client options (like increasing MaxCallSendMsgSize)
issue.body:
### Is there an existing request for this feature?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues for this feature request and I know that duplicates will be closed

### Is your feature request related to a problem?

Yes. If I send a base64 encoded image payload of size larger than 4MB to a server I get an error such as the one in this: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/55362342/grpc-received-message-larger-than-max-8653851-vs-4194304

The reason is that the default upload/download limits of GRPC are set to 4MB. These are configurable and Postman should allow this. 

### Describe the solution you'd like

Postman should allow GRPC client options like [MaxCallSendMsgSize](https://pkg.go.dev/google.golang.org/grpc?utm_source=godoc#MaxCallSendMsgSize) to be configured. 

### Describe alternatives you've considered

None. Looks like this isn't supported in bloom-rpc either. Asking Postman to implement it since they are well-funded.

### Additional context

Refer: 
1. GRPC Go client lib - https://pkg.go.dev/google.golang.org/grpc?utm_source=godoc#MaxCallSendMsgSize
2. GRPC Java client lib - https://grpc.github.io/grpc-java/javadoc/io/grpc/CallOptions.html#withMaxInboundMessageSize-int-

comment.body: @victorthury Postman v9.29.0.

issue.title: [gRPC] scripts should be able to be executed after a response in case of a stream call
issue.body:
### Is there an existing request for this feature?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues for this feature request and I know that duplicates will be closed

### Is your feature request related to a problem?

When invoking a binary/server streaming grpc call, after having received a response, we cannot execute a script, it is only executed when the stream finishes. In my case, I need to keep the stream opened to keep a connection opened, but I also need a token returned by the server in a response, but I cannot automate that and save it in a variable because it is saved only when the stream finishes i.e. the connection is terminated.

### Describe the solution you'd like

That either there two types of script : one after a response is received, the other after the stream is closed, or that the "After response" script is played after a response even when the stream is not closed.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_

comment.body:
Thanks for the feedback, @Thothore.

We plan to add an "After message" or "On message" script which executes after every message received in a streaming RPC. We are currently evaluating all the workflows it will enable.

Can you share more details about your current use case or any other use case which will be unblocked using this?

issue.title: Need to send unencoded characters - Error: Request path contains unescaped characters
issue.body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the tracker for existing similar issues and I know that duplicates will be closed

### Describe the Issue

Hello,

Please allow me to give some background before I jump into this, I understand this issue is commonly reported and answered the same on all the Stackoverflow results.

For years I have been limited to using Insomnia's REST API because it's built using node-libcurl for requests rather than Node's HTTP module (Which I believe Postman is using based on the response I'm getting). The problem is, that Postman is much better built for handling my other use cases and is less buggy in general.

The error is "Error: Request path contains unescaped characters"

If you Google this, you'll see everyone is typically making beginner's mistakes not encoding something correctly. I am performing security research and I *want* to send unencoded space characters ` `, I absolutely and totally do not want it to be encoded and sent as `%20` or any other type of encoded method.

**Why do I want to do this?**

Certain servers behave unexpectedly when using unencoded space characters and it opens up the potential for a lot of abuse and accessing restricted routes which is why I need to be able to do this.

I believe the issue with sending unencoded spaces throwing an error is due to Node's core infrastructure but I'm not 100% certain. I really came here to ask: Does anyone have any sort of fix whatsoever for this? It can be as hacky, weird, strange or whatever verb you want to use but I really want to stop using other clients and stick to Postman. :(


### Steps To Reproduce

1. Disable automatic encoding
2. Put a space between any URL path and send the request

### Screenshots or Videos

_No response_

### Operating System

N/A

### Postman Version

N/A

### Postman Platform

Postman App

### Additional Context?

_No response_

comment.body:
@unreleased I agree entirely with that, and Postman being a debugging client, must enable testing all these workflows.

We are currently using the `node:http` module, which has this limitation.
We've hit multiple such limitations in the past and had unblocked by either overriding the methods at the runtime or directly patching the Node.js source.

This might take a while, but we'll try to unblock this as well. Let me know if you find any workaround for this.

issue.title: Can't import a .proto file if a message's field is called `constructor`
issue.body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the tracker for existing similar issues and I know that duplicates will be closed

### Describe the Issue

When importing a `.proto` file in which there is a message definition containing a field with the name `constructor`, the import fails with the error message 

> duplicate name 'constructor' in Type ...

This issue also persists if I instead create a Protobuf API definition within postman instead of importing a `.proto` message. I am able to create the Protobuf API, but when I try to select it when putting together a gRPC Request, the same error as above appears.

### Steps To Reproduce

1. Import a .proto file
2. Select a .proto file with a message definition that has `constructor` as a field name. See here a minimal example (also attached)
```
syntax = "proto3";

package import_test;

message Foo {
    string bar = 1;
    string constructor = 2;
}
```
3. Click Next
4. You will receive an error message saying 
> `duplicate name 'constructor' in Type Foo`.

If you comment out the definition of the constructor field, everything works as expected.

[import_test.zip](https://github.com/postmanlabs/postman-app-support/files/9147228/import_test.zip)

### Screenshots or Videos

_No response_

### Operating System

Windows

### Postman Version

9.25.1

### Postman Platform

Postman App

### Additional Context?

_No response_

comment.body:
Thanks for the confirmation, @darko-da!

Yes, I am aware of this issue in Server Reflection.
We've identified the root cause in our proto parsing package and trying to push our changes to the upstream to fix for all the dependent packages (including the one used for server reflection).

Can you please file a new bug report for this?
We are updating our Server Reflection implementation soon; we'll address this during that.

issue.title: gRPC: Display additional payload for errors
issue.body:
### Is there an existing request for this feature?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues for this feature request and I know that duplicates will be closed

### Is your feature request related to a problem?

As solved on https://github.com/postmanlabs/postman-app-support/issues/10670, there is a need to see more detailed information regarding the server error beside the error code or message.

In many cases, Google and other service will return an additional `details` property with more structural data regarding the error occurred. The full spec written by Google is here: https://cloud.google.com/apis/design/errors#error_model

### Describe the solution you'd like

As there is no definition for the `details` property, it would be best if the user will able to see the raw data sent by the server and also parse it given a [predefined list of error payloads](https://cloud.google.com/apis/design/errors#error_payloads) or provide a custom error payload to parse for.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

_No response_

### Additional context

In my own environment I wan't able to see the raw data responded from the server, not even on the console. This make it very hard to debug and see the actual payload returned by the server on errors.

issue.title: Can't import a .proto file if a message's field is called `constructor`
issue.body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the tracker for existing similar issues and I know that duplicates will be closed

### Describe the Issue

When importing a `.proto` file in which there is a message definition containing a field with the name `constructor`, the import fails with the error message 

> duplicate name 'constructor' in Type ...

This issue also persists if I instead create a Protobuf API definition within postman instead of importing a `.proto` message. I am able to create the Protobuf API, but when I try to select it when putting together a gRPC Request, the same error as above appears.

### Steps To Reproduce

1. Import a .proto file
2. Select a .proto file with a message definition that has `constructor` as a field name. See here a minimal example (also attached)
```
syntax = "proto3";

package import_test;

message Foo {
    string bar = 1;
    string constructor = 2;
}
```
3. Click Next
4. You will receive an error message saying 
> `duplicate name 'constructor' in Type Foo`.

If you comment out the definition of the constructor field, everything works as expected.

[import_test.zip](https://github.com/postmanlabs/postman-app-support/files/9147228/import_test.zip)

### Screenshots or Videos

_No response_

### Operating System

Windows

### Postman Version

9.25.1

### Postman Platform

Postman App

### Additional Context?

_No response_

comment.body:
@darko-da Thanks for reporting this bug.

We've pushed a fix for this in v9.29. Can you please update your app and confirm if that fixes your issue?

issue.title: Support configuring GRPC client options (like increasing MaxCallSendMsgSize)
issue.body:
### Is there an existing request for this feature?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues for this feature request and I know that duplicates will be closed

### Is your feature request related to a problem?

Yes. If I send a base64 encoded image payload of size larger than 4MB to a server I get an error such as the one in this: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/55362342/grpc-received-message-larger-than-max-8653851-vs-4194304

The reason is that the default upload/download limits of GRPC are set to 4MB. These are configurable and Postman should allow this. 

### Describe the solution you'd like

Postman should allow GRPC client options like [MaxCallSendMsgSize](https://pkg.go.dev/google.golang.org/grpc?utm_source=godoc#MaxCallSendMsgSize) to be configured. 

### Describe alternatives you've considered

None. Looks like this isn't supported in bloom-rpc either. Asking Postman to implement it since they are well-funded.

### Additional context

Refer: 
1. GRPC Go client lib - https://pkg.go.dev/google.golang.org/grpc?utm_source=godoc#MaxCallSendMsgSize
2. GRPC Java client lib - https://grpc.github.io/grpc-java/javadoc/io/grpc/CallOptions.html#withMaxInboundMessageSize-int-

fix: update minimal.js to evade override mistake (#1742)

* Update minimal.js

See https://github.com/Agoric/agoric-sdk/blob/master/patches/%40confio%2Bics23%2B%2Bprotobufjs%2B6.11.3.patch

The original code used assignment to override the `constructor` and `toString` properties inherited from Error.prototype. However, if `Error.prototype` is frozen, as it is under Hardened JS (aka SES) or under the Node frozen intrinsics flag, then this assignment fails due to the JavaScript "override mistake".

`enumerable: true` would accurately preserve the behavior of the original assignment, but I'm guessing that was not intentional. For an actual error subclass, this property would not be enumerable, so my PR currently proposes that. But either would work, so let me know if you'd like me to change it.

`configurable: false` would accurately preserve the behavior of the original, but I'm guessing that was not intentional. For an actual error subclass, this property would be configurable. But either would work, so let me know if you'd like me to change it.

issue.title: Feature Request: Support gRPC prefix path on URL
issue.body:
### Is there an existing request for this feature?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues for this feature request and I know that duplicates will be closed

### Is your feature request related to a problem?

We use Envoy to routing and clustering our back-end services and we use prefix for routing between the services and some gRPC tools such as Kreya and BloomRPC support path on request URL but Postman doesn't support URL path and when I use prefix path on the URL like "grpc://localhost:1337/api" Postman raise error "Failed to parse DNS address dns:localhost:1337/api"

### Describe the solution you'd like

gRPC for calling methods use a string such as: /packagename.ServiceName/MethodName so if we have a request URL for example "grpc://localhost:1337/api" you can parse this URL and use host name and port (localhost:1337) for make connection to server and  if exists a path in the URL (/api in this URL) add into start of the method name before call it like as /api/packagename.ServiceName/MethodName.

thank you so much.

### Describe the Issue

Postman works correctly on local with gRPC, but not working when I try to use it on my remote gRPC server, reflection and method calls doesn't work at all, screenshots and videos attached.

When try to use refleaction getting this:

```
Could not load server reflection.
Details: 13 INTERNAL: Received RST_STREAM with code 2 triggered by internal client error: Protocol error
```

If I add protofile and try to invoke method, I get the same ^ error.

1. Open a new gRPC request tab
2. Add remote server
3. Try to use reflection > ERROR
4. Add protofile manually
5. Try to invoke method > same ERROR

_No response_

### Operating System

macOS

### Postman Version

10.0.30

### Postman Platform

Postman App

### Additional Context?

Well, my gRPC server is deployed on AWS it's behind ALB and deployed to ECS cluster. I tried to use grpcurl tool and it works without any issue, so it's not up to my setup, it's postman thing. If you need more info please let me know. Thanks!

issue.title: URL Encoding not working
issue.body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the tracker for existing similar issues and I know that duplicates will be closed

### Describe the Issue

When "Encode URL Automatically" is enabled, the call request path is not being encoded for specific characters. The characters not being encoded are treated differently when used as a query parameter value. Attached are two screenshots displaying this behavior. The first screenshot is showing the GET request containing multiple # characters in the path and the console log showing the request made is not encoding this character. The second screenshot is showing when I make a request to a different endpoint where it accepts query parameters, the # character is being encoded in the request showing in the console.

### Steps To Reproduce

1. Open a new request
2. Enable the "Encode URL Automatically" setting
3. Update the uri path to include a # character
4. Submit the request and review the console log

Conflicting behavior replication steps
1. Open a new request
2. Enable the "Encode URL Automatically" setting
3. Add a query parameter with a value that includes the # character
4. Submit the request and review the console log

### Screenshots or Videos


![tempsnip2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/96807580/195424301-e3a6c9a5-dee6-467a-a011-88abbc1ba6a4.png)

![tempsnip](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/96807580/195423964-90f5c9a6-faaa-47b6-a6fd-c2f4851e9390.png)


### Operating System

Windows

### Postman Version

10.0.25

### Postman Platform

Postman App

### Additional Context?

_No response_

comment.body: @Ludatick This happens because `#` in a URL string represents a [URI fragment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/URI_fragment). The "Encode URL automatically" setting encodes reserved characters (as per WHATWG spec) in URL segments, but `#` holds a different meaning. It's working for the query-params input because the URL string has `%23`. As a workaround, I will suggest having this Pre-request script to encode `#`s before sending the request. ```js pm.request.url.update(pm.request.url.toString().replace(/#/g, '%23')); ```

issue.title: Support configuring GRPC client options (like increasing MaxCallSendMsgSize)
issue.body:
### Is there an existing request for this feature?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues for this feature request and I know that duplicates will be closed

### Is your feature request related to a problem?

Yes. If I send a base64 encoded image payload of size larger than 4MB to a server I get an error such as the one in this: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/55362342/grpc-received-message-larger-than-max-8653851-vs-4194304

The reason is that the default upload/download limits of GRPC are set to 4MB. These are configurable and Postman should allow this. 

### Describe the solution you'd like

Postman should allow GRPC client options like [MaxCallSendMsgSize](https://pkg.go.dev/google.golang.org/grpc?utm_source=godoc#MaxCallSendMsgSize) to be configured. 

### Describe alternatives you've considered

None. Looks like this isn't supported in bloom-rpc either. Asking Postman to implement it since they are well-funded.

### Additional context

Refer: 
1. GRPC Go client lib - https://pkg.go.dev/google.golang.org/grpc?utm_source=godoc#MaxCallSendMsgSize
2. GRPC Java client lib - https://grpc.github.io/grpc-java/javadoc/io/grpc/CallOptions.html#withMaxInboundMessageSize-int-

issue.title: [gRPC] scripts should be able to be executed after a response in case of a stream call
issue.body:
### Is there an existing request for this feature?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues for this feature request and I know that duplicates will be closed

### Is your feature request related to a problem?

When invoking a binary/server streaming grpc call, after having received a response, we cannot execute a script, it is only executed when the stream finishes. In my case, I need to keep the stream opened to keep a connection opened, but I also need a token returned by the server in a response, but I cannot automate that and save it in a variable because it is saved only when the stream finishes i.e. the connection is terminated.

### Describe the solution you'd like

That either there two types of script : one after a response is received, the other after the stream is closed, or that the "After response" script is played after a response even when the stream is not closed.

_No response_

Can you share more details about your current use case or any other use case which will be unblocked using this?

issue.title: Need to send unencoded characters - Error: Request path contains unescaped characters
issue.body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the tracker for existing similar issues and I know that duplicates will be closed

### Describe the Issue

Hello,

Please allow me to give some background before I jump into this, I understand this issue is commonly reported and answered the same on all the Stackoverflow results.

For years I have been limited to using Insomnia's REST API because it's built using node-libcurl for requests rather than Node's HTTP module (Which I believe Postman is using based on the response I'm getting). The problem is, that Postman is much better built for handling my other use cases and is less buggy in general.

The error is "Error: Request path contains unescaped characters"

If you Google this, you'll see everyone is typically making beginner's mistakes not encoding something correctly. I am performing security research and I *want* to send unencoded space characters ` `, I absolutely and totally do not want it to be encoded and sent as `%20` or any other type of encoded method.

**Why do I want to do this?**

Certain servers behave unexpectedly when using unencoded space characters and it opens up the potential for a lot of abuse and accessing restricted routes which is why I need to be able to do this.

I believe the issue with sending unencoded spaces throwing an error is due to Node's core infrastructure but I'm not 100% certain. I really came here to ask: Does anyone have any sort of fix whatsoever for this? It can be as hacky, weird, strange or whatever verb you want to use but I really want to stop using other clients and stick to Postman. :(


### Steps To Reproduce

1. Disable automatic encoding
2. Put a space between any URL path and send the request

### Screenshots or Videos

_No response_

### Operating System

N/A

### Postman Version

N/A

### Postman Platform

Postman App

### Additional Context?

_No response_

comment.body:
@unreleased I agree entirely with that, and Postman being a debugging client, must enable testing all these workflows.

We are currently using the `node:http` module, which has this limitation.
We've hit multiple such limitations in the past and had unblocked by either overriding the methods at the runtime or directly patching the Node.js source.

This might take a while, but we'll try to unblock this as well. Let me know if you find any workaround for this.

issue.title: Can't import a .proto file if a message's field is called `constructor`
issue.body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the tracker for existing similar issues and I know that duplicates will be closed

### Describe the Issue

When importing a `.proto` file in which there is a message definition containing a field with the name `constructor`, the import fails with the error message 

> duplicate name 'constructor' in Type ...

This issue also persists if I instead create a Protobuf API definition within postman instead of importing a `.proto` message. I am able to create the Protobuf API, but when I try to select it when putting together a gRPC Request, the same error as above appears.

### Steps To Reproduce

1. Import a .proto file
2. Select a .proto file with a message definition that has `constructor` as a field name. See here a minimal example (also attached)
```
syntax = "proto3";

package import_test;

message Foo {
    string bar = 1;
    string constructor = 2;
}
```
3. Click Next
4. You will receive an error message saying 
> `duplicate name 'constructor' in Type Foo`.

If you comment out the definition of the constructor field, everything works as expected.

[import_test.zip](https://github.com/postmanlabs/postman-app-support/files/9147228/import_test.zip)

### Screenshots or Videos

_No response_

Windows

### Postman Version

9.25.1

Postman App

_No response_

issue.title: gRPC: Display additional payload for errors
issue.body:
### Is there an existing request for this feature?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues for this feature request and I know that duplicates will be closed

### Is your feature request related to a problem?

As solved on https://github.com/postmanlabs/postman-app-support/issues/10670, there is a need to see more detailed information regarding the server error beside the error code or message.

In many cases, Google and other service will return an additional `details` property with more structural data regarding the error occurred. The full spec written by Google is here: https://cloud.google.com/apis/design/errors#error_model

### Describe the solution you'd like

As there is no definition for the `details` property, it would be best if the user will able to see the raw data sent by the server and also parse it given a [predefined list of error payloads](https://cloud.google.com/apis/design/errors#error_payloads) or provide a custom error payload to parse for.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

_No response_

### Additional context

In my own environment I wan't able to see the raw data responded from the server, not even on the console. This make it very hard to debug and see the actual payload returned by the server on errors.

Yes. If I send a base64 encoded image payload of size larger than 4MB to a server I get an error such as the one in this: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/55362342/grpc-received-message-larger-than-max-8653851-vs-4194304

The reason is that the default upload/download limits of GRPC are set to 4MB. These are configurable and Postman should allow this. 

### Describe the solution you'd like

Postman should allow GRPC client options like [MaxCallSendMsgSize](https://pkg.go.dev/google.golang.org/grpc?utm_source=godoc#MaxCallSendMsgSize) to be configured. 

### Describe alternatives you've considered

None. Looks like this isn't supported in bloom-rpc either. Asking Postman to implement it since they are well-funded.

### Additional context

Refer: 
1. GRPC Go client lib - https://pkg.go.dev/google.golang.org/grpc?utm_source=godoc#MaxCallSendMsgSize
2. GRPC Java client lib - https://grpc.github.io/grpc-java/javadoc/io/grpc/CallOptions.html#withMaxInboundMessageSize-int-

The original code used assignment to override the `constructor` and `toString` properties inherited from Error.prototype. issue.title: Feature Request: Support gRPC prefix path on URL
issue.body:
### Is there an existing request for this feature?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues for this feature request and I know that duplicates will be closed

### Is your feature request related to a problem?

We use Envoy to routing and clustering our back-end services and we use prefix for routing between the services and some gRPC tools such as Kreya and BloomRPC support path on request URL but Postman doesn't support URL path and when I use prefix path on the URL like "grpc://localhost:1337/api" Postman raise error "Failed to parse DNS address dns:localhost:1337/api"

### Describe the solution you'd like

gRPC for calling methods use a string such as: /packagename.ServiceName/MethodName so if we have a request URL for example "grpc://localhost:1337/api" you can parse this URL and use host name and port (localhost:1337) for make connection to server and  if exists a path in the URL (/api in this URL) add into start of the method name before call it like as /api/packagename.ServiceName/MethodName.

thank you so much.

issue.title: URL Encoding not working
issue.body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the tracker for existing similar issues and I know that duplicates will be closed

### Describe the Issue

When "Encode URL Automatically" is enabled, the call request path is not being encoded for specific characters. The characters not being encoded are treated differently when used as a query parameter value. Attached are two screenshots displaying this behavior. The first screenshot is showing the GET request containing multiple # characters in the path and the console log showing the request made is not encoding this character. The second screenshot is showing when I make a request to a different endpoint where it accepts query parameters, the # character is being encoded in the request showing in the console.

### Steps To Reproduce

1. Open a new request
2. Enable the "Encode URL Automatically" setting
3. Update the uri path to include a # character
4. Submit the request and review the console log

Conflicting behavior replication steps
1. Open a new request
2. Enable the "Encode URL Automatically" setting
3. Add a query parameter with a value that includes the # character
4. Submit the request and review the console log

### Screenshots or Videos


![tempsnip2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/96807580/195424301-e3a6c9a5-dee6-467a-a011-88abbc1ba6a4.png)

![tempsnip](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/96807580/195423964-90f5c9a6-faaa-47b6-a6fd-c2f4851e9390.png)


### Operating System

Windows

### Postman Version

10.0.25

### Postman Platform

Postman App

### Additional Context?

_No response_

comment.body: @Ludatick This happens because `#` in a URL string represents a [URI fragment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/URI_fragment). The "Encode URL automatically" setting encodes reserved characters (as per WHATWG spec) in URL segments, but `#` holds a different meaning. It's working for the query-params input because the URL string has `%23`. As a workaround, I will suggest having this Pre-request script to encode `#`s before sending the request. ```js pm.request.url.update(pm.request.url.toString().replace(/#/g, '%23')); ```

issue.title: Support pm.sendRequest in gRPC scripts.
issue.body: ### Is there an existing request for this feature? - [X] I have searched the existing issues for this feature request and I know that duplicates will be closed ### Is your feature request related to a problem? In HTTP requests pre-request script, it is possible to send http requests with `pm.sendRequest` to perform actions before the request (e.g. retrieve a fresh access token for authentication/authorization), but it seems like the function is not supported in gRPC `Before Invoke` request scripts (see below). ### Describe the solution you'd like Support the function `pm.sendRequest` to send HTTP requests in gRPC scripts. ### Describe alternatives you've considered Checked available [external libraries available in scripts in postman](https://learning.postman.com/labs/postman-api-client/grpc-client/writing-scripts/postman-sandbox-api/#using-external-libraries) to see if one of them supported HTTP requests, but couldn't find any that did. ### Additional context _No response_

issue.title: Support configuring GRPC client options (like increasing MaxCallSendMsgSize)
issue.body:
### Is there an existing request for this feature?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues for this feature request and I know that duplicates will be closed

### Is your feature request related to a problem?

Yes. If I send a base64 encoded image payload of size larger than 4MB to a server I get an error such as the one in this: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/55362342/grpc-received-message-larger-than-max-8653851-vs-4194304

The reason is that the default upload/download limits of GRPC are set to 4MB. These are configurable and Postman should allow this. 

### Describe the solution you'd like

Postman should allow GRPC client options like [MaxCallSendMsgSize](https://pkg.go.dev/google.golang.org/grpc?utm_source=godoc#MaxCallSendMsgSize) to be configured. 

### Describe alternatives you've considered

None. Looks like this isn't supported in bloom-rpc either. Asking Postman to implement it since they are well-funded.

### Additional context

Refer: 
1. GRPC Go client lib - https://pkg.go.dev/google.golang.org/grpc?utm_source=godoc#MaxCallSendMsgSize
2. GRPC Java client lib - https://grpc.github.io/grpc-java/javadoc/io/grpc/CallOptions.html#withMaxInboundMessageSize-int-

issue.title: [gRPC] scripts should be able to be executed after a response in case of a stream call
issue.body:
### Is there an existing request for this feature?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues for this feature request and I know that duplicates will be closed

### Is your feature request related to a problem?

When invoking a binary/server streaming grpc call, after having received a response, we cannot execute a script, it is only executed when the stream finishes. In my case, I need to keep the stream opened to keep a connection opened, but I also need a token returned by the server in a response, but I cannot automate that and save it in a variable because it is saved only when the stream finishes i.e. the connection is terminated.

### Describe the solution you'd like

That either there two types of script : one after a response is received, the other after the stream is closed, or that the "After response" script is played after a response even when the stream is not closed.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_

comment.body:
Thanks for the feedback, @Thothore.

We plan to add an "After message" or "On message" script which executes after every message received in a streaming RPC. We are currently evaluating all the workflows it will enable.

Can you share more details about your current use case or any other use case which will be unblocked using this?

issue.title: Need to send unencoded characters - Error: Request path contains unescaped characters
issue.body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the tracker for existing similar issues and I know that duplicates will be closed

### Describe the Issue

Hello,

Please allow me to give some background before I jump into this, I understand this issue is commonly reported and answered the same on all the Stackoverflow results.

For years I have been limited to using Insomnia's REST API because it's built using node-libcurl for requests rather than Node's HTTP module (Which I believe Postman is using based on the response I'm getting). The problem is, that Postman is much better built for handling my other use cases and is less buggy in general.

The error is "Error: Request path contains unescaped characters"

If you Google this, you'll see everyone is typically making beginner's mistakes not encoding something correctly. I am performing security research and I *want* to send unencoded space characters ` `, I absolutely and totally do not want it to be encoded and sent as `%20` or any other type of encoded method.

**Why do I want to do this?**

Certain servers behave unexpectedly when using unencoded space characters and it opens up the potential for a lot of abuse and accessing restricted routes which is why I need to be able to do this.

I believe the issue with sending unencoded spaces throwing an error is due to Node's core infrastructure but I'm not 100% certain. I really came here to ask: Does anyone have any sort of fix whatsoever for this? It can be as hacky, weird, strange or whatever verb you want to use but I really want to stop using other clients and stick to Postman. :(


### Steps To Reproduce

1. Disable automatic encoding
2. Put a space between any URL path and send the request

### Screenshots or Videos

_No response_

### Operating System

N/A

### Postman Version

N/A

### Postman Platform

Postman App

### Additional Context?

_No response_

comment.body:
@unreleased I agree entirely with that, and Postman being a debugging client, must enable testing all these workflows.

We are currently using the `node:http` module, which has this limitation.
We've hit multiple such limitations in the past and had unblocked by either overriding the methods at the runtime or directly patching the Node.js source.

This might take a while, but we'll try to unblock this as well. Let me know if you find any workaround for this.

issue.title: Can't import a .proto file if a message's field is called `constructor`
issue.body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the tracker for existing similar issues and I know that duplicates will be closed

### Describe the Issue

When importing a `.proto` file in which there is a message definition containing a field with the name `constructor`, the import fails with the error message 

> duplicate name 'constructor' in Type ...

This issue also persists if I instead create a Protobuf API definition within postman instead of importing a `.proto` message. I am able to create the Protobuf API, but when I try to select it when putting together a gRPC Request, the same error as above appears.

### Steps To Reproduce

1. Import a .proto file
2. Select a .proto file with a message definition that has `constructor` as a field name. See here a minimal example (also attached)
```
syntax = "proto3";

package import_test;

message Foo {
    string bar = 1;
    string constructor = 2;
}
```
3. Click Next
4. You will receive an error message saying 
> `duplicate name 'constructor' in Type Foo`.

If you comment out the definition of the constructor field, everything works as expected.

[import_test.zip](https://github.com/postmanlabs/postman-app-support/files/9147228/import_test.zip)

### Screenshots or Videos

_No response_

### Operating System

Windows

### Postman Version

9.25.1

### Postman Platform

Postman App

### Additional Context?

_No response_

comment.body:

Yes, I am aware of this issue in Server Reflection.
We've identified the root cause in our proto parsing package and trying to push our changes to the upstream to fix for all the dependent packages (including the one used for server reflection).

Can you please file a new bug report for this?
We are updating our Server Reflection implementation soon; we'll address this during that.

issue.title: gRPC: Display additional payload for errors
issue.body:
### Is there an existing request for this feature?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues for this feature request and I know that duplicates will be closed

### Is your feature request related to a problem?

As solved on https://github.com/postmanlabs/postman-app-support/issues/10670, there is a need to see more detailed information regarding the server error beside the error code or message.

In many cases, Google and other service will return an additional `details` property with more structural data regarding the error occurred. The full spec written by Google is here: https://cloud.google.com/apis/design/errors#error_model

### Describe the solution you'd like

As there is no definition for the `details` property, it would be best if the user will able to see the raw data sent by the server and also parse it given a [predefined list of error payloads](https://cloud.google.com/apis/design/errors#error_payloads) or provide a custom error payload to parse for.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

_No response_

### Additional context

In my own environment I wan't able to see the raw data responded from the server, not even on the console. This make it very hard to debug and see the actual payload returned by the server on errors.

fix: update minimal.js to evade override mistake (#1742)

* Update minimal.js

See https://github.com/Agoric/agoric-sdk/blob/master/patches/%40confio%2Bics23%2B%2Bprotobufjs%2B6.11.3.patch

The original code used assignment to override the `constructor` and `toString` properties inherited from Error.prototype. However, if `Error.prototype` is frozen, as it is under Hardened JS (aka SES) or under the Node frozen intrinsics flag, then this assignment fails due to the JavaScript "override mistake".

`enumerable: true` would accurately preserve the behavior of the original assignment, but I'm guessing that was not intentional. For an actual error subclass, this property would not be enumerable, so my PR currently proposes that. But either would work, so let me know if you'd like me to change it.

`configurable: false` would accurately preserve the behavior of the original, but I'm guessing that was not intentional. For an actual error subclass, this property would be configurable. But either would work, so let me know if you'd like me to change it.

issue.title: Feature Request: Support gRPC prefix path on URL
issue.body:
### Is there an existing request for this feature?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues for this feature request and I know that duplicates will be closed

### Is your feature request related to a problem?

We use Envoy to routing and clustering our back-end services and we use prefix for routing between the services and some gRPC tools such as Kreya and BloomRPC support path on request URL but Postman doesn't support URL path and when I use prefix path on the URL like "grpc://localhost:1337/api" Postman raise error "Failed to parse DNS address dns:localhost:1337/api"

### Describe the solution you'd like

gRPC for calling methods use a string such as: /packagename.ServiceName/MethodName so if we have a request URL for example "grpc://localhost:1337/api" you can parse this URL and use host name and port (localhost:1337) for make connection to server and  if exists a path in the URL (/api in this URL) add into start of the method name before call it like as /api/packagename.ServiceName/MethodName.

thank you so much.

comment.body: @daneshvar Are you trying to connect to a gRPC-Web server?

issue.title: Toggle Message requests when toggling between interfaces
issue.body:
### Is there an existing request for this feature?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues for this feature request and I know that duplicates will be closed

### Is your feature request related to a problem?

Currently, when I switch between interfaces under the same proto, the content of the message body remains the same. 

### Describe the solution you'd like

I want it to switch with the interface and save the current message body when it switches so it can be used the next time it switches back

### Describe alternatives you've considered

_No response_

issue.title: gRPC: Add metadata to requests for server reflection
issue.body: ### Is there an existing issue for this? - [X] I have searched the existing issues ### Describe the Issue When I try to get the services and methods via Server Reflection, any metadata that I defined is not being passed in. ### Steps To Reproduce 1. Open gRPC request tab 2. Add a new metadata field 3. Attempt to get the proto details via reflection 4. See that the metadata is not passed through ### Screenshots or Videos ### Environment Information ```markdown - Operating System: OSX - Platform Type: Native App - Postman Version: 9.11.0 ``` ### Additional Context? _No response_

comment.body:
@MrLimelab I understand your use case. We are working on it and will let you know when it's released.

Do you have a similar requirement of sending different reflection and request metadata?
